titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: I motored to Cuddesdon, & lunched with the Bishop. We were alone, & had some intimate talk, that is, as intimate as

's evasive & enigmatic temperament permits. Attractive in many respects as he is, and friendly in manner & speech, I have never yet succeeded in getting through his protective crust of foolery. He resembles
in this respect, but whereas in
's case, I suspect an essential frivolity, in
's I incline to believe that there is a fundamental gravity.

affects to think that when all these precious Synods have declared themselves, the Bishops will have sufficient assurance of clerical support to justify their procedure. I reminded him that London, Liverpool, Manchester & Blackburn were considerable exceptions, & that his own Synod had shown a disconcertingly large dissentient minority, & that at least 6 dioceses had no Synods at all. He admitted the seriousness of these facts, but hardly seemed to appreciate their force. After lunch I picked up
in an adjacent house, and returned to Oxford, where I wrote letters, and then dined in a pleasant party with mine hostess.
